description:
Metarhizium album ARSEF 1941 is a species of entomopathogenic fungus, meaning it infects and kills insects. It belongs to the phylum Ascomycota, a group of fungi that produce spore-bearing structures called asci.

Metarhizium album is a soil-borne fungus that can infect and colonize a variety of insect hosts. It produces infectious spores called conidia that can adhere to the insect's cuticle (outer shell), germinate, and penetrate the host's body. Once inside, the fungus grows and proliferates, ultimately killing the insect.

This particular strain, ARSEF 1941, was isolated from a soil sample and is part of the Agricultural Research Service Collection of Entomopathogenic Fungal Cultures (ARSEF) maintained by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA).

Metarhizium album and other Metarhizium species are being studied for their potential use as biological control agents against various insect pests in agricultural and forestry settings, as they can provide an environmentally friendly alternative to chemical pesticides.
